text: this is my son Adam who's setting in the
fifth row there and Adam is trying to
learn his way through this maze he's
trying to learn in his mind to produce a
mental image a map of how this maze is
laid out so that he'll be able to get
out of it quickly when it comes to test
time and he's having a pretty good time
he might get a little bit nauseous from
it but usually they don't and he gets
about ten minutes of practice just
moseying around trying to find how to
get to the exit door and if we do that
and then pop him down into three
different places in the maze and see how
fast he can get out that will give us a
measure of how well he's learned the
maze and then later we can bring him
back and test him again well if we bring
him back let's see let's see if we
trained him there at noon and in this
case just let him take a nap don't even
need a whole night of sleep just a 90
minute nap and then test them about
dinner time what we'd find is that if he
hasn't had a nap if you've been wake
that whole time it'll take him about a
minute longer to find his way out of the
maze than it did when we tested him
right after he learned it but if he's
had a nap he'll be a minute faster so
after you've slept on this your brain
has actually created an image a better
image of how that maze is laid out and
in fact we think now that after you
sleep what your brain is doing is
producing a better image of how the
world works and how you can use but you
learn the day before to help you do
better tomorrow
